fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other pompano species
fish_habitat: Young found in open waters. Adults found to depths of 180 feet, often near reefs, wrecks and ledges.
fish_behavior: Great fighter and good to eat. Often found in schools over structure.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other jack species
fish_habitat: Wide-ranging in offshore waters, not a common catch. Young are associated with sargassum.
fish_behavior: Spawn offshore during spring, summer and fall.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other herrings (menhaden, which are often referred to as “shad,” have a rounder lower jaw tip; American shad is an east coast species)
fish_habitat: Occur from rivers to offshore waters
fish_behavior: Enter freshwater to spawn; young remain in freshwater, then move out to sea with age; feed on plankton; important baitfish
fish_additional: State Record:  This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Also known as true bonito and northern bonito.
fish_habitat: Coastal to offshore waters of the Atlantic Ocean (rarely found in the Gulf).
fish_behavior: Feed on small fishes and invertebrates
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other jack species
fish_habitat: Found offshore and inshore in bays and estuaries.
fish_behavior: Diet includes fishes, invertebrates, plankton and decaying matter.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Spot, L. xanthurus (caudal fin is forked and preopercle is smooth)
fish_habitat: Generally found north of Tampa Bay on the west coast and north of Cape Canaveral on the east coast. Young found in estuaries and older fish (2 to 3 years) inhabit deep offshore waters during the winter months and move into bays and estuaries during the spring, summer and fall.
fish_behavior: Become bronze or yellow in color during spawning. Spawning occurs offshore in fall. Feeds on fishes and invertebrates.
fish_additional: State Record: 4 lbs 15 oz, caught near St. Lucie

fish_habitat: Coastal waters; can be found near the surf zone; common in bays and estuaries.
fish_additional: This abundant, small coastal shark is caught frequently and targeted for their meat as it’s both sold for human consumption and used as bait to target larger species of shark. However, their small fin size makes them less valuable to commercial fisheries than other species of shark. Commonly caught as bycatch in the shrimp fisheries.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: No close resemblance, but frequently called angelfish by mistake
fish_habitat: Inshore, nearshore, over seagrass beds and around structure
fish_behavior: Spawn in spring and summer; travel in large schools; small juveniles may drift on their sides to mimic floating debris; feed on crustaceans and other invertebrates
fish_additional: State Record:  This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Dark blue-gray back, silvery sides and a white bellyLast dorsal fin ray is elongatedSimilar Species: American shad, A. sapidissima; and threadfin shad, D. petenense
fish_habitat: Coastal waters
fish_behavior: Filter-feed on plankton and eat small fishes, crabs and shrimp.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other halfbeaks
fish_habitat: Young are found in open waters. Adults found in bays and nearshore waters close to reefs.
fish_additional: Popular bait species.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other jack species
fish_habitat: Nearshore and offshore over hard bottom, generally in shallower water than other amberjacks. Young associated with weed lines or floating debris and may follow sharks and other large fish.
fish_behavior: Adults feed on fish and shrimp.  Spawning occurs offshore most of year.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Rock sea bass, C. philadelphica (has spot near middle of dorsal base and head is fully-scaled)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters over hard bottom areas.
fish_behavior: Feed on small fishes and invertebrates.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Striped anchovy, A. hepsetus (anal fin begins below middle of dorsal fin)
fish_habitat: Shallow bays and estuaries. Common in brackish waters.
fish_behavior: Form dense schools and tolerate a wide range of salinities.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Also known as goggle-eye.
fish_habitat: Prefers clear oceanic waters.
fish_behavior: Usually nocturnal and feed at night on invertebrates and plankton.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Red drum, S. ocellatus; and sheepshead, A. probatocephalus (both lack barbels on lower jaw)
fish_habitat: Inshore fish common to bays, river mouths and lagoons. Bottom dwellers, often found around oyster beds, docks and bridge pilings. May also be found offshore. Juveniles found in estuaries.
fish_behavior: Largest of drum species. Spawns nearshore in winter and early spring. Feeds on fishes and invertebrates including oysters, mussels, crabs and shrimp. May live to 35 or more years.
fish_additional: Fishing Tips and Facts: The vertical bars on juvenile black drum are somewhat similar to those on sheepshead and spadefish. Anglers typically use cut bait, shrimp, sand fleas or blue crabs as bait, and it is very important to keep the bait on the bottom where the drum feed. Tackle requirements are dependent on the size of fish being targeted, the location and current. Bait-casting or spinning tackle with 15 to 30 pound test line would be suitable for most conditions.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Gag, M. microlepis (spur on preopercle is serrated); and yellowfin grouper, M. venenosa (pectoral fins trimmed in bright yellow)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters near structure. Juveniles can be found inshore. Adults are associated with rocky bottoms, reef, and drop off walls in water over 60 feet deep.
fish_behavior: Spawn during the winter months.
fish_additional: State Record: 113 lb 6 oz, caught near the Dry Tortugas

fish_appearence: Also known as rock bass or rockfish.
fish_habitat: Coastal waters near structure and rocky bottoms.  Smaller specimens are often found inshore in finger channels.
fish_behavior: Spawn January through March and are protogynous hermaphrodites, meaning older females becoming breeding males. Omnivorous bottom feeders, and their diet includes small fish, crustaceans, and shellfish.
fish_additional: State Record: 5 lb, 1 oz, caught near Panama City.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other snappers
fish_habitat: Coastal waters, with adults in deeper water and juveniles in shallower areas.
fish_behavior: Diet mainly consists of fishes.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Yellowfin tuna, T. albacares (elongated second dorsal and anal fins); and bluefin tuna, T. thynnus (has short pectoral fins and reaches a much larger size)
fish_habitat: Coastal to offshore waters
fish_behavior: Feed on small fishes, invertebrates and plankton.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_habitat: Coastal waters. Common in bays and lagoons.
fish_additional: Juvenile blacknose are typically found in shallow water while adults are located at greater depths (over 30 feet).  They are known to form large schools and occasionally associate with schools of mullet and anchovies. This shark poses little threat to humans and has never been reported in a shark attack case.

fish_habitat: Common in Florida's coastal waters, bays, and estuaries.
fish_additional: An active, fast-swimming shark often seen at the surface. Often forms large schools during annual migration times.  Migrates southward and into deeper coastal waters during winter months. May leap out of the water and, like the related spinner shark, spin around several times before dropping back into the sea.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: White marlin, K. albida (dorsal fin rounded with noticeable spots; tip of pectoral and anal fins rounded)
fish_habitat: Offshore waters
fish_behavior: Unlike swordfish, blue marlin feed mostly during the day on fish and squid. They hunt alone and have been reported to use their long, sharp bill to slice or stun prey.
fish_additional: State Record: 1046 lbs, caught near Panama City

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Bluefish, P. saltatrix; crevalle jack, C. hippos (lacks scutes); and other jack species
fish_habitat: Juveniles found offshore. Adults found inshore and nearshore.
fish_behavior: Mature at 9 to 10 inches.
fish_additional: State Record: 8 lb 5 oz, caught near Pensacola

fish_habitat: Found worldwide in temperate and tropical pelagic (open ocean) waters. They rarely approach nearshore areas, but have been documented near oceanic islands and where the continental shelf is narrow.
fish_additional: Although slow-moving, they are not shy and have been documented in shark attacks resulting from at-sea disasters. They are frequently caught as bycatch of longline and driftnet fisheries and sometimes targeted for recreational sports fishing.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Blackfin tuna, T. atlanticus (has long pectoral fins and reaches much smaller size)
fish_habitat: Offshore waters
fish_behavior: Feed on fishes, squid and occasionally crustaceans
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Ladyfish, E. saurus (mouth terminal, at the very front of head)
fish_habitat: Inshore fish inhabiting shallow waters often less than one foot deep, usually over lush seagrass flats, but occasionally over white sand
fish_behavior: Bonefish have deeply forked tails that provide power for chasing prey in lush grass beds. Keen eyesight and a skittish nature make these fish a prized trophy for saltwater anglers. They travel in small schools prowling grass beds and sand flats for shrimp, crabs and other invertebrates. Average size is 3 to 5 pounds but fish weighing more than 10 pounds can be found in Florida. Spawns offshore.
fish_additional: State Record: 16 lb 3 oz, caught near Islamorada

fish_habitat: Abundant in nearshore Florida waters. Commonly seen over shallow sand and mud flats. Moves into deeper coastal waters during the colder months.
fish_additional: Edible, but marketed mostly as crab bait. Good sport fish; use light tackle with live shrimp or cut-bait. Typically, harmless to humans, but can bite if mishandled during catch and release. Often displayed in aquaria.

fish_habitat: Inhabits estuarine, nearshore and offshore waters of both the Gulf and Atlantic coasts of Florida. Bull sharks have a wide range of salinity tolerances and commonly enter freshwater systems as well as hypersaline lagoons.  They are the only shark species that can tolerate long periods of freshwater exposure, sometimes venturing hundreds of miles inland via coastal river systems.
fish_additional: Bull sharks are more aggressive than most shark species and responsible for many unprovoked attacks on humans worldwide.  Some experts consider them to be more dangerous than white or tiger sharks, accounting for the third highest number of attacks on humans.  Constitutes only a small portion of the commercial shark fishery and harvested for their fins, marketable flesh, and hide.  This hardy species also does well in captivity.

fish_habitat: Found near coral reefs in the Caribbean and off South America; rarely found north of the Florida Keys.  Sometimes found lying motionless in coral caves and resting on the bottom of the sea floor.
fish_additional: Protected in Florida state waters and prohibited from harvest in U.S. waters, but now valued more as a living resource for eco-tourism purposes than food due to their accumulation of toxic levels of methylmercury and other heavy metals in their muscle tissue, making them less desirable as marketable flesh. Infrequently associated with shark bites on humans.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Spanish mackerel, S. maculatus (lack yellowish stripe on sides); and king mackerel, S. cavalla (lateral line drops sharply below second dorsal fin)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters, especially over coral reefs and other structure, occurring mainly in south Florida.
fish_behavior: Unlike other mackerels, cero mackerels do not stray far from south Florida waters.  They spawn offhshore in midsummer and feed on small fish and squid.
fish_additional: State Record: 17 lb 2 oz, caught near Islamorada

fish_appearence: Also known as ling or lemonfish.
fish_habitat: Cobia are found in nearshore and inshore waters with inlets and bays. Cobia are frequently found around buoys, pilings and wrecks in these areas.
fish_behavior: They spawn in spring and early summer. Feeds on crabs, squid and small fishes.
fish_additional: State Record: 130 lb 1 oz, caught near Destin

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Blue runner, C. crysos (lack black spot at base of pectoral fins); other jack species.
fish_habitat: Common both inshore and in open waters.
fish_behavior: Tolerate a wide range of salinities. Schools corner a pod of baitfish at the surface. Feed mainly on small fishes. Peak spawning occurs offshore March through September.
fish_additional: State Record: 57 lb, caught near Jupiter

fish_appearence: Also known as cuban snapper.
fish_habitat: Coastal waters near structure. Juveniles found in estuarine areas.
fish_behavior: Among largest snapper species. Not common.  Feed on fishes and larger crustaceans.  Spawning occurs in the late summer in the Keys.
fish_additional: State Record: 116 lb, caught near Clearwater

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Schoolmaster, L. apodus (lack white triangle below eye; fins are more yellow)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters near structure.  Juveniles are found in estuaries.
fish_behavior: Spawn from spring through fall.  Known as night feeders, feeds on fishes and invertebrates.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Also known as mahi-mahi or dorado.
fish_habitat: Offshore in warm waters. Young live in floating sargassum weed.
fish_behavior: Fast swimmers and one of the fastest-growing fish, though to live no more than 5 years. Spawns in warm oceanic currents throughout much of the year. Diet includes flying fish and squid.
fish_additional: State Record: 81 lb, caught near Lantana

fish_habitat: A cosmopolitan species inhabiting continental nearshore areas and offshore waters.  Adults are known to migrate great distances and avoid estuaries with low salinities.  Juveniles congregate in shallow bays and estuaries.
fish_additional: Dusky sharks have been federally protected since 1999 and harvest is prohibited from U.S. federal waters.  Since 2006, Florida has included dusky sharks on the state prohibited species list, therefore, it is unlawful to harvest, possess, land, purchase, sell or exchange this species.  Historically, this species was targeted in commercial shark fisheries mainly for their high-quality fins, flesh, skin, and liver oil.  On a global scale, their populations are considered vulnerable (ICUN). Infrequently associated with shark bites on humans.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Striped mullet, M. cephalus (has stripes and lacks black blotch at base of pectoral fin), and white mullet, M. curema (lacks pigmented second dorsal fin)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters, occurring along beaches in the fall.
fish_behavior: Spawn in nearshore or inshore waters during spring and summer. Juveniles found inshore.  Feed on algae, small crustaceans and decaying matter.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other snook species
fish_habitat: Inshore species found in mangroves. Commonly found in freshwater. Occurs more in freshwater than other snook species.
fish_behavior: Mangrove shorelines serve as nursery grounds for young.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_habitat: Frequents coastal waters, bays and estuarine waters. Commonly seen over mud and sand flats during summer months and moves into deeper coastal waters during the colder months.
fish_additional: Caught as bycatch, but is considered to have little overall economic importance to the commercial shark fishery. This shark poses little threat to humans and has never been reported in a shark bite case.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Permit, T. falcatus (dorsal fin begins over the anal fin and grow much larger than Florida pompano)
fish_habitat: Inshore and nearshore waters, especially along sandy beaches, oyster bars and over seagrass beds, often in turbid water. Found in water as deep as 130 feet.
fish_behavior: Spawn offshore March to September.
fish_additional: State Record: 8 lb 4 oz, caught near Port St. Joe

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Hardhead catfish, A. felis (has four chin barbels and spines lack filaments)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters; may enter brackish waters
fish_behavior: A good food-fish that is usually less common than the hardhead catfish
fish_additional: State Record: 8 lb, 14 oz

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Black grouper, M. bonaci (spur on preopercle is gently rounded, not serrated)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters near structure such as rocky bottoms, reefs and drop-off walls in water over 60 feet deep. Juveniles found in estuaries and seagrass beds
fish_behavior: Born as females but can later become male. Gag and red grouper are the most widely distributed of the Florida groupers. Goliath and Nassau grouper are protected from harvest in Florida waters. Spawn between January and May with some of the more tropical species spawning year-round.
fish_additional: State Record: 80 lb 6 oz, caught near Destin

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Warsaw grouper, H. nigritus (dorsal spines at varying heights)
fish_habitat: Coastal and nearshore waters over structure or muddy bottoms. Young often occur in estuaries, especially around oyster bars. More abundant in southern Florida than in northern waters.
fish_behavior: Spawn during summer months and have a lifespan of 30 to 50 years.
fish_additional: Prohibited from harvest.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Jolthead porgy, C. bajonado (has blue line below eye); other porgy species
fish_habitat: Coastal waters in seagrass beds.
fish_behavior: Feed mainly on invertebrates.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Also known as mangrove snapper, mango or black snapper.
fish_habitat: Coastal waters near structure such as reefs, mangroves and seagrass.  Juveniles may enter freshwater.
fish_behavior: Spawn June through August.  Feeds on crustaceans and small fish.
fish_additional: Gray snapper caught offshore are common 8 to 10 pounds.Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other triggerfish
fish_habitat: Hard-bottoms, reefs and ledges in water depths that exceed 80 feet.
fish_behavior: Triggerfish can raise and lock their first dorsal spine; pressing down on the second dorsal spine acts as a trigger, unlocking the first spine.
fish_additional: State Record: 12 lb 7 oz, caught near Pensacola July 15, 2001

fish_appearence: Size: Up to 106 pounds
fish_habitat: Range inshore to offshore. Young found inshore in seagrass beds.
fish_behavior: Top predator in reef areas, consuming fishes, squid and shrimp.
fish_additional: Consuming larger barracuda may cause ciguatera poisoning.

fish_appearence: Size: Up to 60 inches (176 pounds); common around 40 inches and under 40 pounds
fish_habitat: Offshore species associated with rocky reefs, debris and wrecks, typically in 60 to 240 feet of water. Sometimes caught nearshore in south Florida. Juveniles associate with floating objects and may occur in water less than 30 feet deep.
fish_behavior: Largest of the jacks. Thought to spawn offshore throughout most of the year. Feed on squid, fish, and crustaceans.
fish_additional: Fishing Tips: Anglers typically use 50 to 100 pound tackle, but lighter tackle can also be used in many situations. Amberjack are not shy or picky, so you can make all the noise you want, and almost any lively baitfish will be readily accepted. Commonly used baitfish species include blue runners, pinfish, pigfish, grunts, cigar minnows and sand perch. Because amberjacks like to swim around above the reef, it’s a good idea to use just enough lead to keep the bait in the middle of the water column. When amberjack get excited, they will also come to the surface and explode on top-water plugs, jigs, spoons and diving lures. Amberjack are extremely strong fighters with great endurance. To avoid lost or broken tackle, it’s important to have the drag pre-set to match the strength of the angler and the equipment.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Southern flounder, P. lethostigma (may have 5 or more spots but they are not eyelike); summer flounder, P. dentatus (have 5 or more ocellated or eyelike spots on the body)
fish_habitat: Inshore on sandy or mud bottoms, often ranging into tidal creeks. Occasionally caught on nearshore rocky reefs.
fish_behavior: Right eye migrates over to left side early in life.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Also known as whiting.
fish_habitat: Coastal waters; common in surf zones along beaches.
fish_behavior: Thought to prefer high wave action areas such as sand bars where the crashing waves dislodge and suspend small crabs and other small crustaceans. Feeds on fishes and invertabrates.
fish_additional: Fishing Tips and Facts: Longevity is 4 to 6 years.

fish_appearence: Also known as pogie.
fish_habitat: Nearshore waters
fish_behavior: Spawn offshore across the northern Gulf in the winter; valuable commercial fishery
fish_additional: Image Credit: © Diane Rome Peebles

fish_appearence: The Gulf sturgeon, also known as the Gulf of Mexico sturgeon, is one of seven species of sturgeon found in North America.  Sturgeons are prehistoric species that date back to the time of dinosaurs.  Sturgeons are popular in the food industry as a source of caviar.  They have physical features that separate them from other kinds of fish, such as a spiral valve stomach and cartilaginous skeleton (like sharks and rays); however, they have scutes (hard, protective, large individual body plates) instead of shark’s denticles or bony-fish’s scales.  Gulf sturgeon have barbels located on the underside of the snout, no teeth, rubbery lips, and a suctorial mouth for vacuuming food off the bottom.  The sturgeon's coloring typically is dark brown along the upper (dorsal) side shading to a creamy white-colored belly (Wakeford 2001).  Gulf sturgeon are large fish that can exceed a length of eight feet (2.4 meters), a weight of over 300 pounds (137 kilograms), and possess strength to leap nine feet (2.7 meters) into the air.
fish_habitat: Sturgeon are anadromous, a term used to describe fish that spend a part of their lives in saltwater, yet travel upstream in freshwater rivers to spawn. Such fish return year after year to the same stream where they were hatched. For Gulf sturgeon, which are found from Florida to Louisiana, this means a move from salt to fresh water between February and April and a move downriver between September and November. They spend the winter in the Gulf of Mexico in sandy-bottom habitats six to 100 feet deep, where their diet consists of marine worms, grass shrimp, crabs and a variety of other bottom-dwelling organisms. They eat very little while in freshwater rivers.
fish_behavior: Little is known about the early life stages of the Gulf sturgeon throughout its range.   After the late 1800s, Gulf sturgeon populations declined dramatically, a result of the high demand for their delicious meat and valuable roe, and dam construction, dredging activity and other man-made habitat alterations. The decline prompted state and federal officials to place the sturgeon on the protected species lists in the 1980s and 1990s and to enact a harvesting and possession ban. Today, the free-flowing, spring-fed Suwannee River supports the largest and most robust population of Gulf sturgeon in the state and the wider Gulf of Mexico region. Adults spawn on scoured limestone substrates in the upper reaches of this 200-mile long river. As they swim along, sturgeon occasionally leap out of the water. Every spring and summer, lucky boaters and campers along the Suwannee River witness this spectacle. Power boaters can reduce the risk of injury to themselves and the fish by boating slower during the appropriate time of year. This also increases the chance of seeing the sturgeon and other wildlife along the way.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Gafftopsail catfish, B. marinus (has two chin barbels and spines with long filaments)
fish_habitat: Continental waters; enters brackish waters. Commonly caught from bridges, catwalks, and piers, particularly in passes and inland waterways.
fish_behavior: Males incubate eggs in their mouth
fish_additional: State Record: 3lb, 5oz

fish_appearence: Size: Up to 36 inches
fish_habitat: Rocky bottoms, ledges and reefs offshore; young associated with seagrass beds
fish_behavior: Long, hog-like snout allows them to feed on bottom-dwelling mollusks and crustaceans. Because they tend to root in the sediment in search of small prey, they are not commonly caught on hook and line.
fish_additional: Also known as hog snapper.

fish_appearence: Also known as big-eye jack.
fish_habitat: Often found in schools near offshore reefs
fish_behavior: Diet includes fishes, shrimp and other invertebrates
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Red porgy, P. pagrus (has round rear nostrils); other porgy species
fish_habitat: Coastal waters to 45 m (150 ft.).  They range from Rhode Island to Bermuda, and from the northern Gulf of Mexico to Brazil.
fish_behavior: Feed mainly on invertebrates.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Cero, S. regalis; Spanish mackerel, S. maculatus (both have gently sloping lateral lines and a dark blotch on front of first dorsal fin); and wahoo, A. solandri (first dorsal fin long and continuous)
fish_habitat: Coastal to offshore waters. Often around piers. They may occasionally be found in deep water.
fish_behavior: Spawn offshore in mid-summer. Schooling fish that migrate from south Florida waters in winter northward in spring. Feed mainly on fishes.
fish_additional: State Record: 90 lb, caught near Key West

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Littlehead porgy, C. proridens (has many wavy, dark blue lines on snout)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters over hard bottoms from North Carolina to south Florida and the entire Gulf of Mexico.
fish_behavior: Feed mainly on invertebrates.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Also known as skipjack and ten-pounder
fish_habitat: Inshore fish, found in bays and estuaries; occasionally enter freshwater.
fish_behavior: Spawn offshore, peaking in the fall.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Also known as candy snapper.
fish_habitat: Coastal waters near structure. Most common in south Florida. Juveniles found inshore over grass beds or shallow reefs.
fish_behavior: Spawn March to September. Sexually mature at 6 inches. Feed on the bottom, eating crustaceans, mollusks, and fish.
fish_additional: State Record: 6 lb 6 oz, caught near Pensacola

fish_appearence: Also known as leatherjack.
fish_habitat: Inshore in bays and estuaries, often in turbid water
fish_behavior: Diet includes small fishes and crustaceans
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_habitat: An abundant, inshore tropical shark that inhabits both estuarine and nearshore waters of the Gulf and Atlantic coasts of Florida. Commonly enters estuarine waters and often ventures into freshwater areas, but does not penetrate as far up rivers as the Bull shark. Migrates southward and into deeper waters in the winter months.
fish_additional: Prohibited from harvest in Florida state waters. However, this species is still taken in federal waters and targeted commercially in the longline fishery mainly for their fins, marketable flesh, and hide. Does well in captivity, with young individuals being favorite subjects for physiological and behavioral studies. Has been involved in only a few non-fatal bites on humans.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other jack species
fish_habitat: Found nearshore and offshore. Typically found in deeper waters than other Seriola (commonly 180 - 410 feet deep).
fish_behavior: Smallest of the amberjacks. Believed to spawn offshore. Adults eat fish and squid.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Also known as bonito and blue bonito.
fish_habitat: Coastal to offshore waters
fish_behavior: One of the most common tuna species in our area; feed on small fishes and invertebrates
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Knobbed porgy, C. nodosus (lacks dark blue lines on snout)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters over hard bottoms
fish_behavior: Feed mainly on invertebrates
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other jack species
fish_habitat: Coastal waters and estuaries over hard or sandy bottom
fish_behavior: Juveniles have faint vertical bars that fade with age

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Lane snapper, L. synagris (has yellow stripes and a smaller eye)
fish_habitat: Prefer clear coastal waters, usually over reefs.
fish_behavior: Feeds at night on small fishes and invertebrates.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Mangrove rivulus are the only member of the rivulus family that occurs in North America (Taylor and Snelson 1992).  This species can reach a body length of 2.4 inches (6.1 centimeters).  Mangrove rivulus are olive-colored with a flat back body, rounded tail fin, and small black dots located throughout the body surface (sometimes) (National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association 2009).
fish_habitat: The mangrove rivulus inhabits mangrove forests from southeastern Brazil through the Antilles and Central America to Florida (Taylor 1999).  In Florida, this species is found on the Atlantic coast from the Keys to Volusia County and from the Keys to Tampa Bay on the Gulf Coast (Taylor 1999, Briggs and Brown 1986, S. Taylor pers. comm. 2012).  They are an amphibious/fossorial species (they are capable of living on land and water, burrowers on land).  Most of their time is spent on land where they can be found hidden in rotten wet logs or under moist leaf litter (Taylor et al. 2008).
fish_behavior: The diet of the mangrove rivulus primarily consists of worms, copepods (small crustaceans), mosquito larvae, and their own eggs when held captive (National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association).

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Lane snapper, L. synagris (rounded anal fin)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters near structure.
fish_behavior: Spawn in July and August. Feed on fish, crustaceans, and snails.
fish_additional: State Record: 30 lb 4 oz, caught near the Dry Tortugas

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Red grouper, E. morio (has tiny dark spots near eyes)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters, mostly in south Florida. Juveniles found nearshore and adults occur in deeper waters near structure. Somewhat site specific.
fish_behavior: Form large spawning aggregations, making this species highly vulnerable to overharvest.
fish_additional: State Record: 9 lb, caught near Marathon Key (2007)

fish_habitat: An abundant, coastal, tropical and subtropical shark that inhabits nearshore waters of both the Gulf and Atlantic coasts of Florida. Often seen lying motionless on the bottom. Preferred habitats are coral reefs, rocks, and mangrove islands.
fish_additional: Valued in the Caribbean for its high-quality hide, but is considered a nuisance species in most North American longline fisheries with fins and meat of little value. Does well in captivity and has been used in many physiological and immunological studies. This sluggish bottom-dwelling shark has been involved in only a few bites on humans, most of which were provoked.

fish_appearence: Also known as great pompano.
fish_habitat: Clear water along sandy beaches and bays, and occasionally found over reefs. Most common in south Florida.
fish_behavior: Spawn offshore in spring, summer and fall.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Florida pompano, T. carolinus (dorsal fin begins in front of anal fin)
fish_habitat: Offshore near structure; inshore over grass flats, sand and in channels.
fish_behavior: Spawning occurs primarily in early summer and again in fall.
fish_additional: State Record: 56 lb 2 oz, caught near Ft. Lauderdale

fish_appearence: Also known as a grunt.
fish_habitat: Coastal waters
fish_behavior: Feed on small fishes and invertebrates.
fish_additional: Popular as bait.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Spottail pinfish, D. holbrookii (has dark spot on caudal peduncle); pigfish, O. chrysoptera (no incisor-like teeth; mouth ends below front nostril)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters near structure; may enter freshwater.
fish_behavior: Feed on small fishes and invertebrates; popular live bait.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other snappers
fish_habitat: Common offshore over rocky reefs of the continental shelf to 450 feet deep. Young queen snapper suspend at mid-depths.
fish_behavior: There is little is known about the queen snapper, but it is reported that adults live at depths greater than 400 feet. Mainly consume small fishes and squid
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Also known as redfish.
fish_habitat: Coastal waters. In winter, redfish are found in seagrass, over muddy or sand bottoms, or near oyster bars or spring fed creeks.
fish_behavior: Juvenile redfish are an inshore species until they reach roughly 30 inches (4 years). They then migrate to the nearshore population.
fish_additional: State Record: 52 lb 5 oz, caught near Cocoa (1996)

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Nassau grouper, E. striatus (large black spot on caudal peduncle)
fish_habitat: Bottom-dwelling fish found over hard and muddy bottoms. Juveniles found offshore along with adults greater than 6 years old. Fish from 1 to 6 years occupy nearshore reefs.
fish_behavior: Spawn in April and May. Prefer water temperatures between 66 and 77 degrees F. Like many other grouper, red grouper undergo a sex reversal, young individual females becoming males as they age.
fish_additional: State Record: 42 lb 4 oz, caught near St. Augustine Inlet

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other porgy species (have slit-like rear nostrils)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters over rocky or sandy bottoms.
fish_behavior: Feed on fishes and invertebrates.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Silk snapper, L. vivanus (has a yellow eye); and vermilion snapper, R. aurorubens (has rounded anal fin) Size: Up to 36 inches (35 pounds)
fish_habitat: Offshore near structure. Juveniles are found over sand or mud bottoms.
fish_behavior: Spawn from June to October. Sexual maturity is attained at age 2. Adults can live more than 20 years, possibly even up to 60 years.
fish_additional: State Record: 46 lb 8 oz, caught near Destin

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Bank sea bass, C. ocyurus (lack spot near middle of dorsal fin base and nape lacks scales)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters over hard bottom areas; also found near sand or mud bottoms
fish_behavior: Spawn January through March. Young adults are predominantly female and transform into males as they grow older.  The maximum size for rock sea bass is about 10 inches.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Also known as cigar minnow and hardtail.
fish_habitat: Found mid-water or near the bottom, juveniles sometimes at surface.
fish_behavior: Feed on plankton. Spawn offshore throughout the year.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: White marlin, K. albida; and juvenile blue marlin, M. nigricans (both lack the large sail-like dorsal fin of sailfish)
fish_habitat: Offshore waters
fish_behavior: Sailfish are a rapidly growing species; they reach 4-5 feet in one year. They feed aggressively on small fish and squid. Off southeast Florida, sailfish move inshore to shallow water and spawn near the surface in summer. Females swim slowly with their dorsal fins above water, accompanied by one or more males when spawning.
fish_additional: State Record: 126 lb, caught near Big Pine Key

fish_appearence: The saltmarsh topminnow is a smaller species of the Genus Fundulus (Gilbert 1992).  This species can reach a body length of 1.75 inches (4.4 centimeters).  Saltmarsh topminnows are light brown with two rows of black spots on the midside of the body (Florida Natural Areas Inventory 2001).
fish_habitat: The saltmarsh topminnow inhabits low-salinity salt marshes and estuaries dominated by Spartinacordgrasses from Galveston Bay, Texas, east to the extreme western portion of the Florida panhandle (Peterson et al. 2003).
fish_behavior: The diet of the saltmarsh topminnow primarily consists of insects and a type of crustacean called amphipods (Lopez et al. 2010).

fish_appearence: Also known as white trout.
fish_habitat: Coastal waters over sand bottoms in the Gulf of Mexico (rare in Atlantic waters)
fish_behavior: Mature during their first or second year. They have a prolonged inshore spawning season that extends through the spring and summer. Feeds mainly on small fish and shrimp.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_habitat: True to its name, it prefers coastal and offshore sandy areas of the Florida Gulf and Atlantic coasts. Exclusively a marine species, but known to venture near mouths of rivers and estuarine systems. Essentially a bottom-dwelling species found at depths up to 200 feet, but seasonally migrates into deeper water during summer months and returning to warmer waters during the winter.
fish_additional: Prohibited from recreational and commercial harvest in Florida state waters. Harvest is conditionally allowed through the federal research fisheries commercial harvest program, where NMFS observers are required to be onboard approved commercial vessels. Historically targeted in the longline fishery mainly for their fins, marketable flesh and hide. Due to its size, it is a potentially dangerous species and has been associated with few non-fatal bites on humans.

fish_appearence: Also known as pilchard and greenback.
fish_habitat: Coastal waters
fish_behavior: Popular baitfish that forms schools. Spawns offshore.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Yellowmouth grouper, M. interstitalis (inside and corners of mouth are yellow)
fish_habitat: Nearshore and offshore reefs, ledges and rocky bottoms
fish_behavior: Spawn in late spring. Young undergo a sex transformation from female to male as they becomes older.
fish_additional: State Record: 28 lb 6 oz, caught near Mayport

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Dog snapper, L. jocu (has pale triangle below eye) and gray snapper, L. griseus (lack yellow fins and lack blue stripe below eyes)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters. Adults frequent nearshore, especially around elkhorn coral reefs. Large adults are sometimes found on the continental shelf. Juvenile schoolmaster are found in grassy flats.
fish_behavior: Spawn in July and August. Feed on crustaceans, small fishes, and gastropods.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Also known as convict fish.
fish_habitat: Coastal waters near structure such as oyster bars, seawalls and in tidal creeks. They move nearshore during late winter and early spring for spawning.
fish_behavior: Fractional spawners (they only lay a portion of their eggs at a time) in inshore waters, typically in March and April. They are omnivorous feeding mostly on crustaceans and small fish.
fish_additional: State Record: 15 lb 2 oz, caught near Homosassa

fish_habitat: A cosmopolitan species inhabiting continental nearshore areas and offshore waters of tropical and temperate waters worldwide. A highly migratory species moving seasonally throughout its range.
fish_additional: Incredibly hydrodynamic, this species has been clocked at speeds greater than 25 mph with bursts of 40+ mph, which allows them to leap high out of the water.  A valuable commercial species with marketable flesh and fins. It is also considered a recreationally-important game-fish, sought-after for its ability to leap out of the water when hooked.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Red snapper, L. campechanus (has a red eye)
fish_habitat: Common offshore over rocky ledges in very deep water. Most common in south Florida.
fish_behavior: Spawn late spring through summer. Feed on fishes and crustaceans.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Sand seatrout, C. arenarius (has canine teeth and lacks chin pores)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters; may enter freshwater
fish_behavior: Spawning takes place in shallow, saline portions of bays and other inshore areas, peaking between May and September. Matures by second or third year (by 6 inches). Adults eat crustaceans and small fishes. May live to 6 years.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Also known as white trout.
fish_habitat: Most common over sand or sandy mud bottoms offshore along both the Gulf and Atlantic coasts of Florida. Migrate into bays during cold months.
fish_behavior: Spawn offshore in deep water during spring, summer and fall. Feed on small fish and shrimp.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Also known as oceanic bonito.
fish_habitat: Offshore waters
fish_behavior: Feed on fishes and invertebrates
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: The smalltooth sawfish is a cartilaginous fish that belongs to the Subclass Elasmobranchii, which also includes all sharks and rays.  This dorsally tannish-brown fish can reach a total length of up to 18 feet (5.5 meters) including the saw (Bigelow and Schroeder 1953).  The species’ common and scientific names are derived from its long, flattened, toothed rostrum (nose or beak structure) that extends outward from its flattened head.  The rostrum resembles a saw because it has 24–32 unpaired saw teeth on each side.  Rostral teeth that are lost will not grow back; however, chipped teeth will continue to grow as long as the base is intact (Slaughter and Springer 1968).  The mouth teeth are small and flat like other rays.  The smalltooth sawfish is considered a type of ray, in part because the gill slits are located on the bottom of the body and the pectoral fins are attached to the head.
fish_habitat: Juvenile smalltooth sawfish habitats differ from adult habitats.  Juveniles inhabit coastal areas such as estuaries, river mouths, and bays year-round.  They have been recorded from a variety of habitat types including un-vegetated mud and sand bottoms, especially along red mangrove shorelines.  Also, juveniles use creeks and canals that connect to the main stem of rivers as habitat. (Poulakis et al. 2010, 2011).  Potential habitat includes waters under docks, bridges, and piers.  Juveniles typically inhabit salinities between 18 and 30 parts per thousand (PPT) (the ocean is 35), sometimes miles up rivers (Poulakis et al. 2010, 2011; Simpfendorfer et al. 2011).  Adult smalltooth sawfish are typically found in open water habitats, but have been encountered near coral reefs and occur inshore during the spring when females give birth and mating is thought to occur.  Of seven species of sawfish found worldwide, the only species found in Florida waters is the smalltooth sawfish.  Although the historical range of this species extended from the U.S. down to Brazil, all life stages of smalltooth sawfish are found primarily from Charlotte Harbor, Florida to the Florida Keys (Seitz and Poulakis 2002; Poulakis and Seitz 2004, Mote Marine Laboratory Database).
fish_behavior: Little is known about what the smalltooth sawfish feeds on.  Their diet is thought to consist of crabs, shrimp, small fish, and other bottom-dwelling organisms (Bigelow and Schroeder 1953).  The saw is used to slash at prey in the water column and to dislodge prey from bottom-dwelling habitats.

fish_habitat: Primarily a demersal shark, commonly found in shallow bays, continental shelves, and near offshore banks.  Occasionally found in freshwater; although, it’s unlikely they can survive for extended periods of time in low salinities. Known to migrate seasonally into colder waters during spring and move into warmer waters in the fall.
fish_additional: Since there are multiple species that are similar and difficult to distinguish apart in the fishery, Florida has lumped these into a Mustelus complex. Constitutes only a small portion of the Florida coastal commercial shark fishery, as the bulk of this commercial fishery is landed along the mid-Atlantic coast where it’s targeted for their marketable flesh and hide. This hardy species also does well in captivity and is popular with aquariums. Considered harmless to humans due its small size and its grinding teeth.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other snook species
fish_habitat: Inshore in coastal waters, including mangrove shorelines, seagrass beds, beaches and around structure.
fish_behavior: Begin life as males, but between 18 and 22 inches long some become females. Form schools during spawning season.
fish_additional: State Record: 45 lbs 12 oz, caught near Sebastian

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Gulf flounder, P. albigutta (has only three prominent eyelike spots); summer flounder, P. dentatus (have 5 or more ocellated or eyelike spots on the body)
fish_habitat: Brackish bays and estuaries, sometimes ranging into tidal creeks and freshwater.
fish_behavior: Right eye migrates over to left side early in life.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Also known as whiting.
fish_habitat: Coastal waters. Common in surf zones along beaches. Also in shallow coastal waters with a muddy-sand bottom as well as high salinity bays and estuaries along the coast.
fish_behavior: Thought to prefer high wave action areas such as sand bars where the crashing waves dislodge and suspend small crabs and other small crustaceans. Feeds on fishes and invertebrates.
fish_additional: Fishing Tips and Facts: Longevity is 4 to 6 years.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Cero, S. regalis (has yellowish stripe on sides); and king mackerel, S. cavalla (lateral line drops sharply below second dorsal fin)
fish_habitat: Prevalent throughout Florida waters: inshore, offshore and nearshore. Frequently found over grass beds and reefs. Absent from north Florida waters in winter.
fish_behavior: Schooling fish that migrates northward in spring, returning to southerly waters when water temperature drops below 70 degrees F.  Spawn offshore from spring through summer.
fish_additional: State Record: 12 lb, caught near Ft. Pierce

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Scaled sardine, H. jaguana
fish_habitat: Coastal waters
fish_behavior: An abundant fish that forms schools.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_habitat: A highly migratory species, they are known to travel to Greenland waters during summer months and spend the fall/winter in sub-tropical areas near Georgia.  Although rarely found in Florida waters, they could be found offshore or in coastal areas, usually near the bottom, but known to congregate in large schools and can tolerate brackish water.
fish_additional: Prohibited from commercial or recreational harvest in Florida. Commercially targeted for meat and liver oil in U.S. North Atlantic waters. This species poses little threat to humans; however, caution should be used while handling due to their sharp dorsal spines.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Atlantic croaker, M. undulatus (has strongly serrated preopercle)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters
fish_behavior: Feeds on invertebrates and decaying material.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Pinfish, L. rhomboides (lacks large black spot on caudal peduncle)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters with vegetated bottoms.
fish_behavior: Feed mainly on invertebrates.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Also known as speckled trout.
fish_habitat: Coastal waters over sand bottoms or seagrass beds
fish_behavior: Spawning occurs inshore from March through November. Move into deeper, still waters during colder months.  Feed on baitfish, mullet, shrimp and crabs.
fish_additional: State Record: 17 lb 7 oz, caught near Ft. Pierce

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Bay anchovy, A. mitchilli (anal fin begins below beginning of dorsal fin)
fish_habitat: Shallow bays and estuaries
fish_behavior: Form dense schools and tolerate a wide range of salinities.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Bay anchovy, A. mitchilli (anal fin begins below beginning of dorsal fin)
fish_habitat: Shallow bays and estuaries
fish_behavior: Form dense schools and tolerate a wide range of salinities.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Fantail mullet, M. gyrans; and white mullet, M. curema (both have a black blotch at base of pectoral fin and lack dark stripes)
fish_habitat: Coastal waters
fish_behavior: Adult striped mullet migrate offshore in large schools to spawn.  Juveniles migrate inshore at about 1 inch in size, moving far up tidal creeks. Frequent leapers and feed on algae, decaying matter and other tiny marine life.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Gulf flounder, P. albigutta (has only three prominent eyelike spots); southern flounder, P. lethostigma (may have 5 or more spots but they are not eyelike)
fish_habitat: Inshore and offshore waters on or close to the ocean floor buried in sandy substrate. Found in waters of the Atlantic Ocean from Nova Scotia to the east coast of Florida, but not in the Gulf of Mexico.
fish_behavior: Right eye migrates over to left side early in life.
fish_additional: Average lifespan about 12 to 14 years.

fish_appearence: Size:Up to 15 feet (1400 pounds)
fish_habitat: Deep sea fish found from the surface down below 2,000 feet.
fish_behavior: Swordfish over 200 pounds are generally females and tend to migrate to the surface at night, when most drift fishing occurs. Feed primarily on fishes, but may also consume invertebrates.
fish_additional: State Record: 612 lb 12 oz, caught near Key Largo

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other snook species
fish_habitat: Occurs in inshore estuarine habitats.
fish_behavior: Mangrove shorelines serve as nursery areas for young.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: As juveniles, tarpon resemble ladyfish, E. saurus
fish_habitat: Primarily inshore fish; adults spawn offshore.
fish_behavior: Slow-growing, matures at 7 to 13 years of age. Spawn between May and September. Females may lay more than 12 million eggs. Develop into a ribbon-like larval stage.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other snook species
fish_habitat: Inshore in coastal waters; frequently found in freshwater.
fish_behavior: Feed on small fish and large crustaceans. Mangrove shorelines serve as nursery areas for young. Rare on Florida’s west coast.
fish_additional: State Record: This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_habitat: Adults are observed offshore and in oceanic waters, sometimes wandering close to coastal areas in search of food.  Juveniles inhabit coastal bays and nearshore areas.
fish_additional: Considered harmless to humans, this is a shy species and difficult to approach. Valuable commercial species with marketable flesh, hide, fins, and liver. A popular game fish species, often hooked on the upper lobe of their tail as they try to stun the live bait with their tail.

fish_habitat: Common throughout Florida and occurs worldwide in tropical and warm-temperate waters. Found in a variety of habitats including river mouths, shallow bays, and open ocean.
fish_additional: Prohibited from commercial or recreational harvest in Florida state waters. Valuable commercial species in U.S. federal waters, with marketable flesh, hide, fins, and liver. Tiger sharks are second only to the great white shark in the number of bites on humans worldwide.

fish_appearence: Also known as brown grunt.
fish_habitat: Coastal waters
fish_behavior: Feed on invertebrates, plankton and algae.
fish_additional: Easily caught on small hooks baited with squid or cut bait.

fish_appearence: Also known as mingo or beeliner.
fish_habitat: Offshore over structure.
fish_behavior: Spawns April to September. Females mature at 3 to 4 years of age. Grows slowly.
fish_additional: State Record: 6.19 lbs. Gulf of Mexico in 2017

fish_appearence: Similar Species: King mackerel, S. cavalla (lateral line drops sharply)
fish_habitat: Offshore waters; generally not in schools.
fish_behavior: Known for their tremendous runs and shifts of direction. Feeds on fishes and squid.
fish_additional: State Record: 139 lb, caught near Marathon

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Goliath grouper, E. itajara (dorsal spines all at same height)
fish_habitat: Rocky bottoms in water over 200 feet deep. Juveniles found inshore.
fish_behavior: Feeds on fishes and crustaceans.
fish_additional: State Record: 436 lb 12 oz, caught near Destin

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Spotted seatrout, C. nebulosus (has prominent spots); silver seatrout, C. nothus (bottom half of tail is longer than upper half); and sand seatrout, C. arenarius (lacks dark spots)
fish_habitat: Coastal to offshore waters of the Atlantic (typically not in the Gulf of Mexico); juveniles found in estuaries
fish_behavior: May mature as early as age 1; spawns in nearshore or estuarine areas between April and October; schooling fish; feeds primarily on shrimp and fish.
fish_additional: State Record: 10 lb, caught near Port Canaveral

fish_appearence: Also known as a Key West grunt
fish_habitat: Coastal to offshore waters; juveniles found inshore.
fish_behavior: Make a grunting noise by grinding pharyngeal teeth together.
fish_additional: State Record: 15 lb 8 oz, caught near Key West

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Blue marlin, M. nigricans (dorsal fin pointed and lacks spots; tips of pectoral and anal fins pointed); and longbill spearfish, T. pfluegeri (dorsal fin raised in front, then dips slightly, but remains somewhat high)
fish_habitat: Offshore waters
fish_behavior: Uses its bill to stun fast-moving fishes, then turns to consume them; spawning procedures unknown; ranges throughout the Atlantic and Caribbean; feeds on squid and pelagic fishes
fish_additional: State Record: 161 lb, caught near Miami Beach

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Black grouper, M. bonaci (lacks bright yellow on outer third of pectoral fins)
fish_habitat: Coastal to offshore waters, typically near reefs. Juveniles found in seagrass beds.
fish_behavior: Undergoes sex reversal from female to male in latter part of life. Scientific name translates to "venomous," alluding to the fact that this fish, perhaps more frequently than other groupers, is associated with ciguatera poisoning.
fish_additional: State Record: 34 lb 6 oz, caught near Key Largo

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Gulf menhaden, B. patronus (have small spots trailing the prominent dark spot)
fish_habitat: Found nearshore and in bays and estuaries.
fish_behavior: Feeds by filtering phytoplankton.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Blackfin tuna, T. atlanticus (lacks elongated second dorsal and anal fins)
fish_habitat: Offshore waters
fish_behavior: Spawning peaks in the summer; feed on fishes and invertebrates.
fish_additional: Recreational Regulations

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Scamp, M. phenax (elongated caudal fin rays; lacks yellow on inside and corners of mouth)
fish_habitat: Coastal and offshore waters near structure. Not as common as scamp in the Gulf. Range limited to southern Florida.
fish_behavior: Undergoes sex reversal, young individuals female, older individuals becoming male.
fish_additional: State Record:External Website This species is not currently eligible for a state record.

fish_appearence: Similar Species: Other snappers
fish_habitat: Coastal waters, mainly near coral reefs.
fish_behavior: Found mainly in tropical waters. Spawn in mid-summer.
fish_additional: State Record: 8 lb 9 oz, caught near Ft. Myers
